ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The history of Native Americans in the US education system, from boarding schools to Ivy league institutions like Dartmouth
I learned so much about the history of indigenous peoples in North America and the present situation of many communities as well. My writing and research skills also improved a lot.
I learned lots of information about contemporary Native American history, conflict, and resistance from a Native-centered perspective.
Gathered an understanding of how higher education systems of the US work(ed) to deteriorate the culture of Native Americans

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: readings and discussion 

Weaknesses: I feel like the zoom format made discussions a little slow sometimes, but I think this class would be much better in person.

Strengths: Professor Blackhawk is super fun to have in class, was understanding during the pandemic, and made the class very engaging. The books we read were really great and I enjoyed that he went over how to write an essay in great depth. It was also nice we spent time getting to know eachother in the first few classes it made online school a lot more fun.
Strengths of this course include the small class size, truly Native perspectives, and the final research project. The only weakness would be the occasionally unstructured in class discussions.

Readings were very interesting and the topics covered in class were easy-to-follow
Discussions were very engaging and students were always invited to contribute, they were formatted in a very welcoming way that encouraged participation 
Deadlines were very reasonable

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The books we read were very engaging and I enjoyed them a lot and the presentations were very informative. I think our discussions could've been more lively but it is hard to engage and get that level of discussion on line.
Professor Blackhawk was very understanding of deadline extension requests and absences, even when a discussion had been missed there were opportunities to learn about the topics/ideas covered

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, take a class with Prof Blackhawk. Especially if you are not an indigenous student. There are so few courses at Yale focusing on indigenous studies, and Prof Blackhawk's encouragement towards research and scholarly work positively affected all students. I am not an indigenous student, but I found it very educational not only in terms of coursework but also about being a student at Yale. As a first year seminar, Prof Blackhawk is a supportive figure for first year students.

I would absolutely reccomend this class in fact I think everyone at Yale should have to take a class that relates to indigenous culture or history. It is so important and was a great class in general.

Definitely! It's a great privilege to take a course with Professor Blackhawk and learn from his firsthand perspectives. Additionally our class was very small, which made it a fun little community where we got to learn about each other and our individual backgrounds. The course material is very interesting and extremely pertinent, and most people have little to no knowledge of the full extent of contemporary Native history so its very worthwhile. For Native students I especially recommend this course as you may learn some additional knowledge on top of what you already knew while engaging with Professor Blackhawk and other Native students in a unique environment that doesn't really exist in any other courses in Yale College. The workload of this course is very manageable and the readings are interesting. The final project is intensive but very open-ended and fun, and it was definitely the highlight of this course for me. Overall if you want to take a first year seminar this is a great option, especially for anyone interested in Native studies and a smaller class community!

I would 100% recommend this course. The topics covered are very interesting for any student who is open to learning about Native American history, culture, and education in the US. The readings are not of great difficulty and can be interpreted by all students. You are always invited to share any thoughts and ideas on the topics of the discussion. Professor Blackhawk does a great job at including everyone in the discussion and accommodating dating to different needs. It is an amazing course with an amazing professor.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was only a virtual discussion

extras.title:
HIST 017 01
        American Indians in Higher Ed
